elements.title: Resolve Product-Category Miscommunication Before Evaluation Begins
elements.problem: Taline responded to a Craigslist ad believing she was contacting a standard full-time rental listing. She had zero understanding of Split Lease's model -- part-time repeat stays, multi-local guests, variable nightly pricing. Her very first substantive question ('is it for a certain time?' at 0:52) reveals she has no framework for the product she is engaging with. She learned the model did not match her need only after investing time in a phone call, at which point Bryant told her 'unfortunately I won't be able to help you with that... he's not interested in full-time rentals' (3:09). This is a miscommunication that spans discovery through evaluation: the guest believes she is evaluating one product category (traditional rental) while the platform offers another (part-time shared arrangement). The d.school book identifies this exact pattern: 'What the students thought might be the need and what they actually found turned out to be two very different things' (line 86). The current process relies on a human phone call to surface the mismatch, which means guests who never call -- or who hang up when confused -- are permanently lost.
elements.solution: Surface the product category clearly at every guest touchpoint before evaluation begins. This means: (1) Any external listing (Craigslist, social media, referral link) must state in the first line what Split Lease IS and what it is NOT. 'Part-time rental: 2-5 nights per week. Not a full-time lease.' The guest should self-select or self-exclude before investing time. (2) The first screen a guest sees on the platform should explain the model in 10 words or fewer with a visual (e.g., a calendar showing a M-F pattern). The guest must understand the category before seeing any specific listing. (3) If a guest's stated need does not match the model (e.g., they indicate 'full-time, 7 nights/week'), the platform should immediately explain the mismatch AND suggest how the model could still work for them -- mimicking what Bryant did when he suggested M-F stays. Do not just reject; redirect. (4) The miscommunication resolution must happen in under 30 seconds, not over a 3-minute phone conversation.

evidence.quote: I just wanted to know, like that, is it for a certain time?
evidence.insight: Taline's first question reveals she has no understanding of the product category. She is asking the most basic possible question about what the listing even is. This means the discovery channel (Craigslist) communicated nothing about the Split Lease model.

evidence.quote: Yeah, my full time... Unfortunately I won't be able to help you with that. So I work with Ken specifically to find these types of guests. So he's not interested in full-time rentals.
evidence.insight: The product-category mismatch is surfaced and resolved only through a live phone call, after 3 minutes of conversation. The guest's primary need is rejected mid-evaluation, which is a high-risk moment. A self-service flow would have either lost her entirely (no explanation) or never attracted her (if the ad was transparent). The design challenge is to surface AND resolve the mismatch, not just surface it.

evidence.quote: What the students thought might be the need and what they actually found turned out to be two very different things.
evidence.insight: The d.school team found that entering a situation with fixed expectations about the problem leads to discovering the real problem is entirely different. Taline's situation is identical: she expected a rental listing and found a different product category. The design must anticipate this expectation gap and close it proactively.

evidence.quote: Like so many great tales, this story starts with a miscommunication.
evidence.insight: The book frames miscommunication as the generative starting point for design innovation. For Split Lease, the miscommunication between 'what guests expect' and 'what the platform offers' is the single largest pre-evaluation dropout risk. Designing to resolve this miscommunication is the foundational process pattern for the guest journey.

elements.user_goal: Understand within seconds whether this platform can solve my housing problem, without needing to call someone or read through pages of explanation.
elements.company_goal: Eliminate wasted agent time on calls with guests whose needs fundamentally do not match the model, while simultaneously converting guests who could adapt their needs -- like Taline -- before they bounce from confusion.
elements.time_budget: 30 seconds maximum from first touchpoint to product-category comprehension. If the guest does not understand 'this is part-time rental, not full-time' within 30 seconds, the discovery channel has failed.
anti_goals: DO NOT assume guests already understand what Split Lease is. Every touchpoint must assume zero prior knowledge of the model.

DO NOT simply reject guests whose needs do not match. Rejecting without redirecting ('we cannot help you with full-time') loses guests who could adapt. Always pair rejection with an alternative framing.
DO NOT bury the model explanation in FAQ pages, 'About Us' sections, or secondary content. The model must be the FIRST thing communicated, not supplementary information.

DO NOT use platform jargon ('multi-local guests,' 'periodic tenancy,' 'utilization-based pricing') to explain the model. Use the guest's language: 'a place to stay during the work week' or 'Monday through Friday rental.'
elements.success_metric: Pre-call model comprehension rate: percentage of guests who can correctly describe the Split Lease model (part-time, not full-time) before their first human interaction. Target: above 70%. Secondary: reduction in agent calls where the primary topic is explaining the basic model.

elements.title: Enable Guest Self-Adaptation with Structured Alternatives
elements.problem: Taline's journey survived the product-category mismatch only because she improvised an adaptation in real time: she shifted from 'full-time' (3:02) to 'Monday through Friday' (3:53) to 'five nights and then I can do the weekends at my mom' (3:37) in under 60 seconds. This adaptation was catalyzed entirely by human conversation -- Bryant mentioned 'five nights a week' as an example (3:21), and Taline connected it to her own situation. Without this human prompt, she had no way to see that her need could be reshaped to fit the model. The platform currently has no mechanism to support this adaptation. A self-service flow would present the listing as-is, and a guest whose stated need does not match would simply leave. The d.school book describes this as entering a situation 'without being fixed on the exact problem they would tackle' (line 86), but Taline WAS fixed on her problem (full-time housing) until Bryant's suggestion opened a new frame. The platform must provide this reframing without requiring a human agent.
elements.solution: When a guest's stated need does not perfectly match a listing or the platform model, present structured alternatives that help the guest see how their need could be reshaped. This means: (1) If a guest indicates 7-night/week need, immediately show: 'Many guests stay Monday-Friday and spend weekends elsewhere. Would this work for you?' with a cost comparison (5-night vs. 7-night pricing elsewhere). (2) Present adaptation as a benefit, not a compromise. Taline's adaptation saved her money and gave her weekends with family. Frame alternatives around the guest's actual life context, not around the platform's constraints. (3) Provide a 'stay pattern builder' where the guest can drag nights on a weekly calendar and see how different patterns affect pricing. This is the digital equivalent of Bryant's conversational suggestion. (4) Show real examples: 'Guests like you typically stay M-F for work and go home on weekends. Here is what that costs.' Normalize the adapted pattern so it does not feel like settling.

evidence.quote: Yeah, my full time... [Bryant: Five nights a week is likely something that you would be interested in] ... And I just do it like Monday through Friday, I work a lot, so I just really need a place.
evidence.insight: Taline's adaptation happened in under 60 seconds, but only because a human agent suggested a specific alternative. She went from 'my full time' to 'Monday through Friday' because Bryant gave her a concrete frame to adapt into. Without this prompt, she would have had to invent the alternative herself under pressure -- or more likely, hang up.

evidence.quote: Five nights and then I can do the weekends at my mom.
evidence.insight: The adaptation is not just accepting fewer nights -- it is restructuring her entire weekly logistics. She has already figured out the weekend fallback (mom's place). The platform should help guests complete this life-logistics puzzle, not just present a binary stay/leave decision.

evidence.quote: They went into the situation without being fixed on the exact problem they would tackle.
evidence.insight: The d.school students succeeded because they remained open to redefining the problem. Taline succeeded for the same reason -- she was willing to redefine her housing need. But the d.school students had coaching, frameworks, and a safe environment. Taline had none of these. The platform must provide the structured support that enables this kind of productive redefinition.

evidence.quote: None of these assignments has to be used exactly as written. Each is meant to be tinkered with, adapted, and remixed.
evidence.insight: The book's core principle is that creative solutions emerge from tinkering with constraints, not from rigid compliance. The guest's stay pattern should be tinkerable: adjustable nights, flexible start dates, explorable pricing variations. The platform should make adaptation feel like creative exploration, not like downgrading.

elements.user_goal: See quickly whether there is a version of this arrangement that works for my actual life, even if my initial request does not match exactly -- without needing to figure out the alternatives on my own.
elements.company_goal: Convert guests whose initial stated need does not match the model by proactively showing adapted alternatives, recovering leads that would otherwise be lost at the 'we cannot help you' moment.
elements.time_budget: Under 15 seconds to see one relevant alternative pattern after the mismatch is identified. Under 60 seconds to explore 2-3 pattern variations with indicative pricing.
anti_goals: DO NOT present adaptation as a compromise or downgrade. Frame it as a different arrangement that may actually be better (cheaper, more flexible, fits their life pattern).
DO NOT require the guest to invent alternatives themselves. The platform must suggest concrete, specific patterns -- not open-ended 'what works for you?' questions.
DO NOT show only one alternative. Taline adapted to M-F, but other guests might adapt to 3 nights/week, or alternate weeks, or weekdays-only for one month. Show the range of patterns.

DO NOT make the adaptation path a dead end. If the guest selects an adapted pattern, it should flow directly into proposal creation with pricing, not loop back to another search or another conversation.
elements.success_metric: Adaptation conversion rate: percentage of guests who initially indicate a non-matching need (e.g., full-time) and successfully convert to a matching pattern (e.g., M-F) through the platform's alternative suggestions. Target: above 30%. Baseline: currently 0% without human agent intervention.

elements.title: Surface Indicative Pricing Before Agent Mediation
elements.problem: Taline's most direct evaluation question -- 'So I just want to know how much would it cost' (2:51) -- could not be answered during the call. Bryant said 'I have sort of a general idea, but not exact, just because typically these nightly pricing will be set specific on the situation' (5:33-5:50). The single most important piece of information for a budget-constrained guest with two jobs and a child is deferred to a future conversation between the agent and the host. Taline cannot evaluate, cannot compare, cannot decide, and cannot plan. She is left in a state of information limbo where she has invested time and adapted her needs but cannot complete the most basic evaluation: can I afford this? The d.school book emphasizes that learning comes through 'the experience of trying, and failing, and trying again' (line 32), but Taline has no mechanism to try -- she cannot see any price point to react to, test against her budget, or use as a basis for negotiation.
elements.solution: Provide indicative pricing at every stage before exact pricing is confirmed. This means: (1) On every listing or external ad, show a price range: '$X-$Y per night depending on your schedule.' The range does not need to be exact; it needs to be informative enough for the guest to determine if this is in their budget universe. (2) When a guest specifies their pattern (e.g., M-F, starting Dec 15), immediately show an estimated monthly cost based on typical rates for similar arrangements. Label it clearly: 'Estimated cost: $X/month for 5 nights/week. Final pricing confirmed after host review.' (3) Build a pricing calculator that lets the guest adjust nights-per-week and duration and see how the estimated cost changes in real time. This is the 'tinkering' the d.school book advocates -- the guest can experiment with configurations before committing to a proposal. (4) Never leave a guest without a price signal. Even 'similar stays in this area cost $60-$90/night' is better than 'pricing will be set specific on the situation.'

evidence.quote: So I just want to know how much would it cost.
evidence.insight: The most direct evaluation question a guest can ask. Taline needs this number to make a life decision (can I afford to move out of my mom's place?). The inability to answer it during the evaluation phase is the single biggest barrier to conversion.

evidence.quote: I have sort of a general idea, but not exact, just because typically these nightly pricing will be set specific on the situation.
evidence.insight: Even the agent cannot provide pricing. The opacity is structural, not personal -- the pricing model requires host-specific input that has not been gathered yet. But the guest does not care about the reason. She needs a number to plan her life around. Indicative pricing (even a range) would give her something to work with.

evidence.quote: These kinds of realizations don't come from just understanding an idea -- they come through the experience of trying, and failing, and trying again.
evidence.insight: The book argues that understanding emerges from experimentation, not explanation. Taline cannot experiment with pricing because no pricing is available to experiment with. A pricing calculator would let her 'try' different stay patterns and see how costs change -- turning pricing from an opaque wait into an interactive exploration.

evidence.quote: When faced with an open-ended challenge that doesn't have one fixed, right solution, we can all feel like beginners.
evidence.insight: Pricing in Split Lease is genuinely open-ended -- it varies by pattern, duration, and host preference. But presenting this variability as opacity ('I cannot tell you the price') makes the guest feel helpless. Presenting it as a range with a calculator makes the guest feel empowered to find the right solution within the range.

elements.user_goal: Know, within a reasonable range, what this arrangement will cost me before I invest more time, adapt my expectations, or wait for a callback -- so I can decide whether to proceed or look elsewhere.
elements.company_goal: Reduce the evaluation-to-proposal dropout rate by giving guests enough pricing information to self-qualify (budget fits) or self-disqualify (budget does not fit) without consuming agent time. Convert more qualified guests by keeping them engaged through the wait for exact pricing.
elements.time_budget: Under 10 seconds to see an indicative price range on any listing. Under 30 seconds to get a personalized estimate after entering their preferred stay pattern.
anti_goals: DO NOT show exact pricing that the host has not approved. Indicative pricing must be clearly labeled as an estimate, not a commitment.
DO NOT hide pricing entirely until the host confirms. The gap between 'I see no price' and 'here is the exact price' is where guests are lost. Fill that gap with ranges and estimates.
DO NOT require the guest to speak with an agent before seeing any pricing signal. The pricing signal should precede the human interaction, not follow it.
DO NOT present the pricing variability as a problem ('pricing depends on situation'). Present it as flexibility ('you can adjust your pattern to fit your budget').
elements.success_metric: Pricing-informed evaluation rate: percentage of guests who see an indicative price before their first agent interaction. Target: 100%. Secondary: reduction in agent calls where the primary question is 'how much does it cost?'

elements.title: Replace Agent-Gated Progress with Self-Service Momentum
elements.problem: Taline's entire forward path depends on a single human action: Bryant talking to Ken and getting back to her. She cannot create a proposal, explore availability, see pricing, or take any independent action toward securing housing. The call ends with 'I can talk to him and talk to him about your situation. And I get back to you on that' (5:22-5:33) and 'feel free to text me' (6:20). There is no timeline, no status tracker, no self-service path, and no platform scaffolding for the wait. For a guest with a hard deadline (lease ending, needs housing by December 15th) and real stakes (child's school commute), this unstructured wait is high-risk. The d.school book notes that 'success is never about a single moment of insight' (line 69), yet Taline's journey is entirely gated by a single moment: whether and when Bryant follows up. Every hour of delay is an hour she may find another option or lose motivation.
elements.solution: Design the post-call journey to give the guest forward momentum independent of agent action. This means: (1) Immediately after the call, send the guest a confirmation text/email summarizing what was discussed: 'You are interested in a M-F stay starting Dec 15 in North Bergen. Bryant is checking availability with the host. Expected response: within 24 hours.' (2) Give the guest a status page or link where they can see where things stand: 'Step 1: Your needs captured. Step 2: Host review (in progress). Step 3: Pricing proposal. Step 4: Your confirmation.' (3) While waiting for the host's response, show the guest other potentially matching listings in the area: 'While we confirm this listing, here are 2 other options in North Bergen that fit your M-F pattern.' This keeps the guest engaged with the platform rather than returning to Craigslist. (4) Set an SLA for agent response and communicate it clearly: 'Bryant will respond within 24 hours. If you do not hear back, text this number.' (5) Allow the guest to modify their request while waiting: 'Want to adjust your dates or pattern? Update here and we will include the changes in the host review.'

evidence.quote: I can talk to him and talk to him about your situation. And I get back to you on that.
evidence.insight: The entire next step depends on a single human follow-up with no timeline, no confirmation, and no platform mechanism. If Bryant is busy, sick, or simply delays by 48 hours, Taline may have already found another option. The agent is a single point of failure.

evidence.quote: Let me know if you have any questions about the space or anything else that comes up, feel free to text me.
evidence.insight: The only post-call touchpoint is an unstructured text channel. There is no confirmation email, no saved summary, no status visibility. If Taline forgets Bryant's number or the details of the call, the entire interaction is lost.

evidence.quote: But success is never about a single moment of insight.
evidence.insight: The book argues that creative outcomes emerge from sustained engagement, not single breakthroughs. Taline's journey is structured around a single gated moment (Bryant's callback). Redesigning for sustained engagement -- giving the guest things to do, explore, and track while waiting -- converts a fragile single-moment dependency into a durable ongoing relationship.

evidence.quote: We try things out before we know exactly what will happen, and then we spend time thinking and talking about what, exactly, just happened.
evidence.insight: The d.school principle of 'trying before knowing' suggests a design where the guest can take provisional actions (save the listing, explore alternatives, set a budget) before the exact terms are confirmed. This keeps the guest active and invested rather than passively waiting.

elements.user_goal: Know exactly what happens next, when it will happen, and have something I can do in the meantime -- rather than sitting with a promise and a phone number and no visibility into what is happening.
elements.company_goal: Reduce post-call dropout by maintaining guest engagement during the agent-host consultation period. Convert the highest-risk gap in the guest journey (between call and proposal) from dead time into platform engagement time.
elements.time_budget: Confirmation summary sent within 5 minutes of call end. Status page accessible immediately. Alternative listings shown within 10 seconds of status page load. Agent SLA: response within 24 hours.
anti_goals: DO NOT leave the guest with zero platform presence after a call. The call must result in a digital artifact (summary, status page, saved listing) that the guest can return to.
DO NOT promise a callback without a timeline. 'I will get back to you' with no timeframe is anxiety-inducing for an urgent guest. Always set an expectation, even if approximate.
DO NOT make the guest repeat information if they call again or text. Everything discussed in the first call should be captured and accessible to any agent.
DO NOT treat the wait period as dead time. Every day the guest waits without engagement is a day they may solve their problem elsewhere.
elements.success_metric: Post-call retention rate: percentage of guests who receive a post-call summary AND return to the platform at least once before receiving a proposal. Target: above 50%. Secondary: average time between call end and guest receiving a concrete proposal (target: under 24 hours).

elements.title: Capture Life-Context Data to Enable Proactive Matching
elements.problem: Taline's housing decision is shaped by factors that no listing page or search filter captures: her son's school location and pickup schedule (4:25-4:41), her weekday commute to work (4:55: 'my job is literally 30 minutes from my house'), her Saturday job at a different location, her mother's house as a weekend fallback, and her lease ending with a hard deadline. These are not preferences -- they are hard constraints that determine whether any arrangement is viable. Bryant learned some of this through conversation, but the platform has no mechanism to capture, store, or use this information. A listing that is 5 minutes from Taline's son's school is dramatically more valuable to her than one 40 minutes away, but the platform cannot distinguish between them because it does not know where her son goes to school. The d.school book emphasizes 'engaging people intentionally to learn more about their lives' (line 52) and the 'A Day in the Life' exercise (assignment 47) as design foundations. Split Lease is designing a family's daily logistics, not just a room booking.
elements.solution: Build a guest profile that captures life-context data beyond basic housing preferences, and use this data to proactively match and filter listings. This means: (1) During onboarding or first interaction, ask the guest 3-5 life-context questions: 'Where do you work?', 'Do you have school-age children? Where do they go to school?', 'What days of the week do you need housing?', 'Do you have a fallback location for nights you are not staying here?' (2) Use this data to calculate commute times from each listing to the guest's key locations (work, school, fallback home). Show these commute times on every listing: 'This listing is 12 minutes from your workplace and 8 minutes from your son's school.' (3) Flag listings that would create logistical problems: 'This listing is 45 minutes from your son's school -- this may not work for morning drop-off.' (4) During the active lease phase, use the weekly pattern data to send proactive reminders: 'Your M-F stay starts tomorrow. Check-in details for Monday...' and 'Your stay ends Friday. Weekend at your mom's -- see you Monday.'

evidence.quote: I don't want to stay at my mom because my job for me to commute and have to pick up my son from school far from me.
evidence.insight: Taline's housing decision is inseparable from her son's school commute. This is not a 'nice to have' -- it is the primary reason she cannot stay at her mom's place. Any listing evaluation that ignores this constraint is evaluating the wrong thing.

evidence.quote: I just do it like Monday through Friday, I work a lot, so I just really need a place. And then on the weekend I have another job, but I work Saturdays.
evidence.insight: Taline's weekly life pattern is complex: M-F at the rental, Saturday at a second job, Sunday presumably at her mom's. This is a full life structure that the platform must understand and support, not just a booking schedule.

evidence.quote: Engaging people intentionally to learn more about their lives and spark new ideas.
evidence.insight: The d.school's core method is learning about people's lived contexts, not just their stated needs. Taline's stated need is 'a place for two months.' Her lived context is: single mother, two jobs, son in school, commute constraints, family fallback. The platform that captures and uses the lived context will serve her dramatically better than one that knows only 'looking for 2BR in North Bergen.'

evidence.quote: When you design, you shape the world for others, whether you're redesigning the evening routine for your family or an entire public health system.
evidence.insight: Split Lease is literally redesigning Taline's family's evening routine: where she picks up her son, where they sleep, how the week is structured. Acknowledging this responsibility means the platform must capture enough life context to ensure the arrangement actually works for the family's daily logistics, not just for the booking calendar.

elements.user_goal: Have the platform understand my actual life situation -- where I work, where my kid goes to school, what my weekly pattern looks like -- so it can show me listings that actually work for my life, not just listings that are available.
elements.company_goal: Increase match quality and reduce post-booking churn by using life-context data to proactively filter and rank listings. Reduce 'discovered after move-in' problems (commute too long, school pickup impossible) that cause early lease breaks.
elements.time_budget: Life-context questions should take under 2 minutes to complete during onboarding. Commute time display should be instant on every listing. Weekly pattern setup should take under 30 seconds.
anti_goals: DO NOT collect life-context data without using it visibly. If the guest tells you about their son's school and never sees it reflected in search results or listing evaluations, the data collection feels invasive rather than helpful.

DO NOT make life-context questions mandatory for first-time browsing. Let guests explore first, then prompt for context when they show interest in a specific listing: 'Want to see commute times? Tell us where you work.'
DO NOT assume life contexts are static. A guest's job, school, or weekly pattern may change. Provide easy editing and show how changes affect their current arrangement.
DO NOT use life-context data only for matching. Use it throughout the active lease for proactive support: reminders, schedule adjustments, commute alerts.
elements.success_metric: Life-context completion rate: percentage of guests who provide at least 3 life-context data points (work location, weekly pattern, key constraint). Target: above 40% of guests who reach listing evaluation. Secondary: correlation between life-context completion and booking-to-retention rate.

elements.title: Design the Negotiation as Supported Exploration, Not Adversarial Rejection
elements.problem: Taline experienced the negotiation phase as a sequence of rejection and self-rescue. First, her primary need was rejected ('unfortunately I won't be able to help you with that,' 3:09). Then she had to invent an alternative under pressure, in real time, with no support ('And I just do it like Monday through Friday,' 3:53). Then she had to justify her adaptation with emotional vulnerability ('I just really need a place,' 4:14; 'I don't want to stay at my mom because my job for me to commute and have to pick up my son from school far from me,' 4:25-4:41). The emotional arc was: hope, rejection, scramble, tentative recovery. This worked only because (a) Taline is resilient and motivated, and (b) Bryant is a skilled conversationalist who caught her adapted need and validated it. The platform cannot rely on guest resilience or agent skill. The d.school book notes that 'the product is important, but how to get there deserves at least as much attention, if not more' (line 33). The negotiation PROCESS shaped Taline's experience as much as the outcome will.
elements.solution: Redesign negotiation as a supported, exploratory process rather than a binary accept/reject interaction. This means: (1) Never present a flat rejection without a simultaneous alternative. Instead of 'this listing is not available for full-time stays,' show 'this listing is available for 2-5 night/week stays. Here is what that looks like for you.' (2) Use progressive disclosure in negotiation: start with what IS possible, then let the guest narrow from there. Show the full range of stay patterns available for a listing, let the guest select or customize, and calculate pricing for each option. (3) Provide emotional framing that normalizes adaptation: 'Most guests in your area stay M-F and spend weekends elsewhere. Here is how they describe the arrangement.' Use social proof to make the adapted pattern feel normal, not like settling. (4) Preserve the guest's dignity throughout. Taline had to explain her childcare situation and financial pressure to justify her needs. The platform should never require emotional justification for a stay pattern. A guest selects M-F; the platform does not need to know why.

evidence.quote: Unfortunately I won't be able to help you with that... [Taline adapts] ... And I just do it like Monday through Friday.
evidence.insight: The negotiation arc from rejection to adaptation took ~45 seconds of human conversation. It succeeded because Bryant suggested an alternative and Taline was resilient enough to accept it. A platform flow must achieve the same outcome without depending on either agent skill or guest resilience.

evidence.quote: I just really need a place. And then on the weekend I have another job, but I work Saturdays... I don't want to stay at my mom because my job for me to commute and have to pick up my son from school far from me.
evidence.insight: Taline discloses significant personal vulnerability (financial stress, childcare logistics, family dynamics) during the negotiation. This emotional labor should not be required by the platform. The negotiation process should be functional and supportive, not confessional.

evidence.quote: The product is important, but how to get there deserves at least as much attention, if not more.
evidence.insight: The negotiation process is itself a product of the platform, not just a means to a booking. Taline's experience of negotiation -- rejection followed by self-rescue -- is the product she experienced. Designing this process to feel supportive rather than adversarial is as important as the final booking terms.

evidence.quote: We're hard on work but soft on people, and we don't confuse kindness with weakness.
evidence.insight: The d.school principle of being 'soft on people' while maintaining standards applies directly to negotiation design. The platform can be firm about what is available (part-time only) while being kind about how alternatives are presented (supportive, normalized, with clear benefits).

elements.user_goal: Explore what is possible for my situation without feeling rejected, pressured, or required to justify my personal circumstances -- and arrive at an arrangement that works for my life.
elements.company_goal: Convert more guests through the negotiation phase by replacing rejection moments (which lose guests) with exploration moments (which engage guests). Reduce emotional friction that causes guests to abandon after being told their initial need cannot be met.
elements.time_budget: Under 30 seconds from the guest discovering a mismatch to seeing a viable alternative. Under 2 minutes to explore and select a stay pattern that works. Zero time spent justifying personal circumstances.
anti_goals: DO NOT present any interaction as a rejection. 'Not available for full-time' is a rejection. 'Available for 2-5 nights/week -- explore options' is an invitation.
DO NOT require the guest to explain why they need a particular pattern. The guest selects their pattern; the platform does not need their reason.
DO NOT make the adapted arrangement feel like a downgrade. Frame part-time stays positively: cost savings, flexibility, lifestyle fit.
DO NOT rely on guest resilience as a design input. The platform must work for guests who would hang up at the first 'no,' not just for guests like Taline who push through.
elements.success_metric: Negotiation completion rate: percentage of guests who encounter a need-mismatch moment and successfully arrive at a viable adapted pattern, without agent intervention. Target: above 40%. Baseline: currently 0% without agent, unknown % with agent.
